title: 104_hr833
content: The "Family Planning Amendments Act of 1995" may be cited as the short title. Project grants and contracts for family planning services are addressed in the Act. The "Family Planning Amendments Act of 1995" requires family planning projects to provide pregnancy management information through qualified professionals holding medical degrees or meeting specific criteria determined by the Secretary. The Family Planning Amendments Act of 1995 mandates that family planning projects offer pregnancy management information through qualified professionals or individuals permitted by State law. Projects or providers objecting on religious or moral grounds are not obligated to provide such information but must refer individuals to alternative sources. Information includes nondirective counseling and referrals on pregnancy management options. The Family Planning Amendments Act of 1995 requires family planning projects to offer pregnancy management information, including counseling and referrals on prenatal care, infant care, adoption, and termination of pregnancy. Entities performing abortions must comply with state laws on parental notification and consent to receive grants or contracts under section 1001 of the Public Health Service Act. The Family Planning Amendments Act of 1995 allows states to enforce parental notification or consent laws for minors seeking abortions. The Secretary may only award grants for family planning projects that distribute FDA-approved condoms for pregnancy and STD prevention. The Family Planning Amendments Act of 1995 authorizes grants for projects promoting condom use to prevent pregnancy and STDs. It also advises on the limitations of condom usage and allocates funds for fiscal years 1996 and 1997. The Family Planning Amendments Act of 1995 authorizes appropriations for training grants and contracts totaling $6,250,000 for fiscal year 1996 and $7,000,000 for fiscal year 1997. It also authorizes appropriations for informational and educational materials amounting to $12,000,000 for fiscal year 1996 and $13,500,000 for fiscal year 1997. The Act and its amendments take effect upon enactment.
